explanation:
The correct calculation recognizes that the 78° angle and angle \( t \) are corresponding angles formed by parallel lines and a transversal, making them equal: \( t = 78^\circ \).

The student likely treated the 78° angle and \( t \) as co-interior angles, adding them to reach 90°: \( 78^\circ + t = 90^\circ \rightarrow t = 12^\circ \).

The error stems from misclassifying the relationship between the angles and assuming they sum to 90°, a misunderstanding of co-interior angle properties. The angles are not co-interior (they lie on opposite sides of the transversal relative to the parallel lines), and co-interior angles actually sum to 180°, not 90°. This distinguishes the error from related misconceptions like confusing corresponding angles (which sum to 180° if misapplied) or miscalculating angles on a straight line (which would involve adjacent angles, not these two). The specific 12° result aligns uniquely with an erroneous 90° co-interior sum.
